verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:1
verses.text: Book II.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:3
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:4
verses.text: Long enough has our work been intermitted, and impatient is Love, nor have tears a measure, unless to Love is given what is loved: wherefore, let us enter upon the Second Book.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:5
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:6
verses.text: Let us enter upon it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:7
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:8
verses.text: Let us believe that God will be present.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:9
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:10
verses.text: Let us believe indeed, if even this is in our power.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:11
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:12
verses.text: Our power He Himself is.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:13
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:14
verses.text: Therefore pray most briefly and perfectly, as much as thou canst.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:15
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:16
verses.text: God, always the same, let me know myself, let me know Thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:17
verses.text: I have prayed.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:18
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:19
verses.text: Thou who wilt know thyself, knowest thou that thou art? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:20
verses.text: I know.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:21
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:22
verses.text: Whence knowest thou? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:23
verses.text: I know not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:24
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:25
verses.text: Feelest thou thyself to be simple, or manifold? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:26
verses.text: I know not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:27
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:28
verses.text: Knowest thou thyself to be moved? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:29
verses.text: I know not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:30
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:31
verses.text: Knowest thou thyself to think? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:32
verses.text: I know.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:33
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:34
verses.text: Therefore it is true that thou thinkest.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:35
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:36
verses.text: True.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:37
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:38
verses.text: Knowest thou thyself to be immortal? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:39
verses.text: I know not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:40
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:41
verses.text: Of all these things which thou hast said that thou knowest not: which dost thou most desire to know? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:42
verses.text: Whether I am immortal.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:43
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:44
verses.text: Therefore thou lovest to live? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:45
verses.text: I confess it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:46
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:47
verses.text: How will the matter stand when thou shalt have learned thyself to be immortal? Will it be enough? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:48
verses.text: That will indeed be a great thing, but that to me will be but slight.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:49
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:50
verses.text: Yet in this which is but slight how much wilt thou rejoice? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:51
verses.text: Very greatly.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:52
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:53
verses.text: For nothing then wilt thou weep? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:54
verses.text: For nothing at all.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:55
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:56
verses.text: What if this very life should be found such, that in it it is permitted thee to know nothing more than thou knowest? Wilt thou refrain from tears? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:57
verses.text: Nay verily, I  will weep so much that life should cease to be.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:58
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:59
verses.text: Thou dost not then love to live for the mere sake of living, but for the sake of knowing.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:60
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:61
verses.text: I grant the inference.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:62
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:63
verses.text: What if this very knowledge of things should itself make thee wretched? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:64
verses.text: I do not believe that that is in any way possible.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:65
verses.text: But if it is so, no one can be blessed; for I am not now wretched from any other source than from ignorance of things.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:66
verses.text: And therefore if the knowledge of things is wretchedness, wretchedness is everlasting.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:67
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:68
verses.text: Now I see all which you desire.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:69
verses.text: For since you believe no one to be wretched by knowledge, from which it is probable that intelligence renders blessed; but no one is blessed unless living, and no one lives who is not: thou wishest to be, to live and to have intelligence; but to be that thou mayest live, to live that thou mayest have intelligence.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:70
verses.text: Therefore thou knowest that thou art, thou knowest that thou livest, thou knowest that thou dost exercise intelligence.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:71
verses.text: But whether these things are to be always, or none of these things is to be, or something abides always, and something falls away, or whether these things can be diminished and increased, all things abiding, thou desirest to know.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:72
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:73
verses.text: So it is.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:74
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:75
verses.text: If therefore we shall have proved that we are always to live, it will follow also that we are always to be.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:76
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:77
verses.text: It will follow.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:78
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 1:79
verses.text: It will then remain to inquire concerning intellection.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:2
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:3
verses.text: I see a very plain and compendious order.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:4
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:5
verses.text: Let this then be the order, that you answer my questions cautiously and firmly.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:6
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:7
verses.text: I attend.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:8
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:9
verses.text: If this world shall always abide, it is true that this world is always to abide? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:10
verses.text: Who doubts that? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:11
verses.text: What if it shall not abide? is it not then true that the world is not to abide? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:12
verses.text: I dispute it not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:13
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:14
verses.text: How, when it shall have perished, if it is to perish, will it not then be true, that the world has perished? For as long as it is not true that the world has come to an end, it has not come to an end: it is therefore self-contradictory, that the world is ended and that it is not true that the world is ended.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:15
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:16
verses.text: This too I grant.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:17
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:18
verses.text: Furthermore, does it seem to you that anything can be true, and not be Truth? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:19
verses.text: In no wise.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:20
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:21
verses.text: There will therefore be Truth, even though the frame of things should pass away.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:22
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:23
verses.text: I cannot deny it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:24
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:25
verses.text: What if Truth herself should perish? will it not be true that Truth has perished? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:26
verses.text: And even that who can deny? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:27
verses.text: But that which is true cannot be, if Truth is not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:28
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:29
verses.text: I have just conceded this.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:30
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:31
verses.text: In no wise therefore can Truth fail.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:32
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 2:33
verses.text: Proceed as thou hast begun, for than this deduction nothing is truer.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:3
verses.text: Now I will have you answer me, does the soul seem to you to feel and perceive, or the body? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:4
verses.text: The soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:5
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:6
verses.text: And does the intellect appear to you to appertain to the soul? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:7
verses.text: Assuredly.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:8
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:9
verses.text: To the soul alone, or to something else? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:10
verses.text: I see nothing else besides the soul, except God, in which I believe intellect to exist.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:11
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:12
verses.text: Let us now consider that.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:13
verses.text: If any one should tell you that wall was not a wall, but a tree, what would you think? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:14
verses.text: Either that his senses or mine were astray, or that he called a wall by the name of a tree.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:15
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:16
verses.text: What if he received in sense the image of a tree, and thou of a wall? may not both be true? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:17
verses.text: By no means; because one and the same thing cannot be both a tree and a wall.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:18
verses.text: For however individual things might appear different to us as individuals, it could not be but that one of us suffered a false imagination.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:19
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:20
verses.text: What if it is neither tree nor wall, and you are both in error? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:21
verses.text: That, indeed, is possible.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:22
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:23
verses.text: This one thing therefore you had past by above.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:24
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:25
verses.text: I confess it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:26
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:27
verses.text: What if you should acknowledge that anything seemed to you other than it is, are you then in error? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:28
verses.text: No.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:29
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:30
verses.text: Therefore that may be false which seems, and he not be in error to whom it seems.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:31
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:32
verses.text: It may be so.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:33
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:34
verses.text: It is to be allowed then that he is not in error who sees falsities, but he who assents to falsities.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:35
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:36
verses.text: It is assuredly to be allowed.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:37
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:38
verses.text: And this falsity, wherefore is it false? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:39
verses.text: Because it is otherwise than it seems.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:40
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:41
verses.text: If therefore there are none to whom it may seem, nothing is false.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:42
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:43
verses.text: The inference is sound.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:44
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:45
verses.text: Therefore the falsity is not in the things, but in the sense; but he is not beguiled who assents not to false things.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:46
verses.text: It results that we are one thing, the sense another; since, when it is misled, we are able not to be misled.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:47
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:48
verses.text: I have nothing to oppose to this.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:49
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:50
verses.text: But when the soul is misled, do you venture to say that you are not false? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:51
verses.text: How should I venture? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:52
verses.text: But there is no sense without soul, no falsity without sense.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:53
verses.text: Either therefore the soul operates, or cooperates with the falsity.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:54
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 3:55
verses.text: Our preceding reasonings imply assent to this.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:3
verses.text: Give answer now to this, whether it appears to you possible that at some time hereafter falsity should not be.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:4
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:5
verses.text: How can that seem possible to me, when the difficulty of discovering truth is so great that it is absurder to say that falsity than that Truth cannot be.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:6
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:7
verses.text: Do you then think that he who does not live, can perceive and feel? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:8
verses.text: It cannot be.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:9
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:10
verses.text: It results then, that the soul lives ever.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:11
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:12
verses.text: Thou urgest me too fast into joys: more slowly, I pray.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:13
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:14
verses.text: But, if  former inferences are just, I see no ground of doubt concerning this thing.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:15
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:16
verses.text: Too fast, I say.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:17
verses.text: Therefore I am easier to persuade that I have made some rash concession, than to become already secure concerning the immortality of the soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:18
verses.text: Nevertheless evolve this conclusion, and show how it has resulted.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:19
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:20
verses.text: You have said that falsity cannot be without sense, and that falsity cannot but be: therefore there is always sense.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:21
verses.text: But no sense without soul: therefore the soul is everlasting.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:22
verses.text: Nor has it power to exercise sense, unless it lives.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 4:23
verses.text: Therefore the soul always lives.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:2
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:3
verses.text: O leaden dagger! For thou mightest conclude that man is immortal if I had granted thee that this universe can never be without man, and that this universe is eternal.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:4
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:5
verses.text: You keep a keen look-out.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:6
verses.text: But yet it is no small thing which we have established, namely, that the frame of things cannot be without the soul, unless perchance in the frame of things at some time hereafter there shall be no falsity.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:7
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:8
verses.text: This consequence indeed I allow to be involved.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:9
verses.text: But now I am of opinion that we ought to consider farther whether former inferences do not bend under pressure.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:10
verses.text: For I see no small step to have been made towards the immortality of the soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:11
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:12
verses.text: Have you sufficiently considered whether you may not have conceded something rashly? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:13
verses.text: Sufficiently indeed, but I see no point at which I can accuse myself of rashness.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:14
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:15
verses.text: It is therefore concluded that the frame of things cannot be without a living soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:16
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:17
verses.text: So far as this, that in turn some souls may be born, and others die.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:18
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:19
verses.text: What if from the frame of things falsity be taken away? will it not come to pass that all things are true? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:20
verses.text: I admit the inference.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:21
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:22
verses.text: Tell me whence this wall seems to thee to be true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:23
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:24
verses.text: Because I am not misled by its aspect.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:25
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:26
verses.text: That is, because it is as it seems.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:27
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:28
verses.text: Yes.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:29
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:30
verses.text: If therefore anything is thereby false because it seems otherwise than it is, and thereby true because it is as it seems; take away him to whom it seems, and there is neither anything false, nor true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:31
verses.text: But if there is no falsity in the frame of things, all things are true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:32
verses.text: Nor can anything seem except to a living soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:33
verses.text: There remains therefore soul in the frame of things, if falsity cannot be taken away; there remains, if it can.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:34
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:35
verses.text: I see our former conclusions somewhat strengthened, indeed; but we have made no progress by this amplification.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 5:36
verses.text: For none the less does that fact remain which chiefly shakes me that souls are born and pass away, and that it comes about that they are not lacking to the world, not through their immortality, but by their succession.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:3
verses.text: Do any corporeal, that is, sensible things, appear to you to be capable of comprehension in the intellect? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:4
verses.text: They do not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:5
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:6
verses.text: What then? does God appear to use senses for the cognition of things? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:7
verses.text: I dare affirm nothing unadvisedly concerning this matter; but as far as there is room for conjecture, God in no wise makes use of senses.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:8
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:9
verses.text: We conclude therefore that the only possible subject of sense is the soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:10
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:11
verses.text: Conclude provisionally as far as probability permits.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:12
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:13
verses.text: Well then; do you allow that this wall, if it is not a true wall, is not a wall? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:14
verses.text: I could grant nothing more willingly.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:15
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:16
verses.text: And that nothing, if it be not a true body, is a body? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:17
verses.text: This likewise.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:18
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:19
verses.text: Therefore if nothing is true, unless it be so as it seems; and if nothing corporeal can appear, except to the senses; and if the only subject of sense is the soul; and if no body can be, unless it be a true body: it follows that there cannot be a body, unless there has first been a soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:20
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 6:21
verses.text: Thou dost urge me too strongly, and means of resistance fail me.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:3
verses.text: Give now still greater heed.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:4
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:5
verses.text: Behold me ready.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:6
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:7
verses.text: Certainly this is a stone; and it is true on this condition, if it is not otherwise than it seems; and it is not a stone, if it is not true; and it cannot seem except to the senses.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:8
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:9
verses.text: Yes.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:10
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:11
verses.text: There are not therefore stones in the most secluded bosom of the earth, nor anywhere at all where there are not those who have the sense of them; nor would this be a stone, unless we saw it; nor will it be a stone when we shall have departed, and no one else shall be present to see it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:12
verses.text: Nor, if you lock your coffers well, however much you may have shut up in them, will they have anything.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:13
verses.text: Nor indeed is wood itself wood interiorly.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:14
verses.text: For that escapes all perceptions of sense which is in the depth of an absolutely opaque body, and so is in no wise compelled to be.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:15
verses.text: For if it were, it would be true; nor is anything true, unless because it is so as it appears: but that does not appear; it is not therefore true: unless you have something to object to this.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:16
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:17
verses.text: I see that this results from my previous concessions; but it is so absurd, that I would more readily deny any one of these, than concede that this is true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:18
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:19
verses.text: As you please.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:20
verses.text: Consider then which you prefer to say: that corporeal things can appear otherwise than to the senses, or that there can be another subject of sense than the soul, or that there is a stone or something else but that it is not true, or that Truth itself is to be otherwise defined.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:21
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 7:22
verses.text: Let us, I pray thee, consider this last position.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:3
verses.text: Define therefore the True.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:4
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:5
verses.text: That  is true which is so as it appears to the knower, if he will and can know.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:6
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:7
verses.text: That therefore will not be true which no one can know? Then, if that is false which seems otherwise than it is; how if to one this stone should seem a stone, to another wood? will the same thing be both false and true? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:8
verses.text: That former position disturbs me more, how, if anything cannot be known, it results from that that it is not true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:9
verses.text: For as to this, that one thing is both true and false, I do not much care.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:10
verses.text: For I see one thing, compared with diverse things, to be both greater and smaller.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:11
verses.text: From which it results, that nothing is more or less of itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:12
verses.text: For these are terms of comparison.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:13
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:14
verses.text: But if you say that nothing is true of itself, do you not fear the inference, that nothing is of itself? For whereby this is wood, thereby is it also true wood.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:15
verses.text: Nor can it be, that of itself, that is, without a knower, it should be wood, and should not be true wood.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:16
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:17
verses.text: Therefore thus I say and so I define, nor do I fear lest my definition be disapproved on the ground of excessive brevity: for to me that seems to be true which is.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:18
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:19
verses.text: Nothing then will be false, because whatever is, is true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:20
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:21
verses.text: Thou hast driven me into close straits, and I am wholly unprovided of an answer.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 8:22
verses.text: So it comes to pass that whereas I am unwilling to be taught except by these questionings, I fear now to be questioned.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:3
verses.text: God, to whom we have commended ourselves, without doubt will render help, and set us free from these straits, if only we believe, and entreat Him most devoutly.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:4
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:5
verses.text: Nothing, assuredly, would I do more gladly in this place; for never have I been involved in so great a darkness.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:6
verses.text: God, Our Father, who exhortest us to pray, who also bringest this about, that supplication is made to Thee; since when we make supplication to Thee, we live better, and are better: hear me groping in these glooms, and stretch forth Thy right hand to me.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:7
verses.text: Shed over me Thy light, revoke me from my wanderings; bring Thyself into me that I may likewise return into Thee, Amen.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:8
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:9
verses.text: Be with me now, as far as thou mayest, in most diligent attention.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:10
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:11
verses.text: Utter, I pray, whatever has been suggested to thee, that we perish not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:12
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:13
verses.text: Give heed.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:14
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 9:15
verses.text: Behold, I have neither eyes nor ears but for thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:3
verses.text: First let us again and yet again ventilate this question, What is falsity? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:4
verses.text: I wonder if there will turn out to be anything, except what is not so as it seems.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:5
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:6
verses.text: Give heed rather, and let us first question the senses themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:7
verses.text: For certainly what the eyes see, is not called false, unless it have some similitude of the true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:8
verses.text: For instance, a man whom we see in sleep, is not indeed a true man, but false, by this very fact that he has the similitude of a true one.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:9
verses.text: For who, seeing a dog, would have a right to say that he had dreamed of a man? Therefore too that is thereby a false dog, that it is like a true one.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:10
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:11
verses.text: It is as thou sayest.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:12
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:13
verses.text: And moreover, if any one waking should see a horse and think he saw a man, is he not hereby misled, that there appears to him some similitude of a man? For if nothing should appear to him except the form of a horse, he cannot think that he sees a man.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:14
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:15
verses.text: I fully concede this.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:16
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:17
verses.text: We call that also a false tree which we see in a picture, and a false face which is reflected from a mirror, and a false motion of buildings to men that are sailing from them, and a false break in the oar when dipped, for no other reason than the verisimilitude in all these things.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:18
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:19
verses.text: True.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:20
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:21
verses.text: So we make mistakes between twins, so between eggs, so between seals stamped by one ring, and other such things.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:22
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:23
verses.text: I follow and agree to all.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:24
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:25
verses.text: Therefore that similitude of things which pertains to the eyes, is the mother of falsity.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:26
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 10:27
verses.text: I cannot deny it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:3
verses.text: But all this forest of facts, unless I am mistaken, may be divided into two kinds.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:4
verses.text: For it lies partly in equal, partly in inferior things.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:5
verses.text: They are equal, when we say that this is as like to that as that to this, as is said of twins, or impressions of a ring.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:6
verses.text: Inferior, when we say that the worse is like the better.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:7
verses.text: For who, looking in a mirror, would dream of saying that he is like that image, and not rather that like him? And this class consists partly in what the soul undergoes, and partly in those things which are seen.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:8
verses.text: And that again which the soul undergoes, it either undergoes in the sense, as the unreal motion of a building; or in itself from that which it has received from the senses, such as are the dreams of dreamers, and perhaps also of madmen.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:9
verses.text: Furthermore, those things which appear in the things themselves which we see, are some of them from nature, and some expressed and framed by living creatures.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:10
verses.text: Nature either by procreation or reflection effects inferior similitudes.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:11
verses.text: By procreation, when to parents children like them are born; by reflection, as from mirrors of various kinds.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:12
verses.text: For although it is men that make the most of the mirrors, yet it is not they that frame the images given back.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:13
verses.text: On the other hand, the works of living creatures are seen in pictures, and creations of the like kind: in which may also be included (conceding their occurrence) those things which demons produce.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:14
verses.text: But the shadows of bodies, because with but a slight stretch of language they may be described as like their bodies and a sort of false  bodies, nor can be disputed to be submitted to the judgment of the eyes, may reasonably be placed in that class, which are brought about by nature through reflection.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:15
verses.text: For every body exposed to the light reflects, and casts a shadow in the opposite direction.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:16
verses.text: Or do you see any objection to be made? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:17
verses.text: None.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 11:18
verses.text: I am only awaiting anxiously the issue of these illustrations.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:3
verses.text: We must, however, wait patiently, until the remaining senses also make report to us that falsity dwells in the similitude of the true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:4
verses.text: For in the sense of hearing likewise there are almost as many sorts of similitudes: as when, hearing the voice of a speaker, whom we do not see, we think it some one else, whom in voice he resembles; and in inferior similitudes Echo is a witness, or that well-known roaring of the ears themselves, or in timepieces a certain imitation of thrush or crow, or such things as dreamers or lunatics imagine themselves to hear.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:5
verses.text: And it is incredible how much false tones, as they are called by musicians, bear witness to the truth, which will appear hereinafter: yet they too (which will suffice just now) are not remote from a resemblance to those which men call true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:6
verses.text: Do you follow this? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:7
verses.text: And most delightedly.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:8
verses.text: For here I have no trouble to understand.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:9
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:10
verses.text: Then, to press on, do you think it is easy, by the smell, to distinguish lily from lily, or by the taste honey from honey, gathered alike from thyme, though brought from different hives, or by the touch to note the difference between the softness of the plumage of the goose and of the swan? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:11
verses.text: It does not seem easy.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:12
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:13
verses.text: And how is it when we dream that we either smell or taste, or touch such things? Are we not then deceived by a similitude of effects and images, inferior in proportion to its emptiness? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:14
verses.text: Thou speakest truly.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:15
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:16
verses.text: Therefore it appears that we, in all our senses, whether by equality or inferiority of likeness, are either misled by cozening similitude, or even if we are not misled, as suspending our consent, or discovering the difference, yet that we name those things false which we apprehend as like the true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:17
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 12:18
verses.text: I cannot doubt it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:3
verses.text: Now give heed, while we run over the same things once more, that what we are endeavoring to show may come more plainly to view.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:4
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:5
verses.text: Lo, here I am, speak what thou wilt.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:6
verses.text: For I have once for all resolved to endure this circuitous course, nor will I be wearied out in it, hoping so ardently to arrive at length whither I perceive that we are tending.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:7
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:8
verses.text: You do well.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:9
verses.text: But take note whether it seems to you, when we see a resemblance in eggs, that we can justly say that any one of them is false.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:10
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:11
verses.text: Far from it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:12
verses.text: For if all are eggs, they are true eggs.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:13
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:14
verses.text: And when we see an image reflected from a mirror, by what signs do we apprehend it to be false? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:15
verses.text: By the fact that it cannot be grasped, gives forth no sound, does not move independently, does not live, and by innumerable other properties, which it were tedious to detail.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:16
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:17
verses.text: I see you are averse to delay, and regard must be borne to your haste.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:18
verses.text: Then, not to recall every particular, if those men also whom we see in dreams, were able to live, speak, be grasped by waking men, and there were no difference between them and those whom when awake and sane we address and see, should we then have any reason to call them false? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:19
verses.text: What possible right could we have to do so? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:20
verses.text: Therefore if they were true, in exact proportion as they were likest the truth, and as no difference existed between them and the true and false so far as they were, by those or other differences, convicted of being dissimilar; must it not be confessed that similitude is the mother of truth, and dissimilitude of falsehood? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 13:21
verses.text: I have no answer to make, and I am ashamed of my former so hasty assent.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 14:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 14:3
verses.text: It is ridiculous if you are ashamed, as if it were not for this very reason that we have chosen this mode of discourse: which, since we are talking with ourselves alone, I wish to be called and inscribed Soliloquies; a new name, it is true, and perhaps a grating one, but not ill suited for setting forth the fact.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 14:4
verses.text: For since Truth can not be better sought than by asking and answering, and scarcely any one can be found who does not take shame to be worsted in debate, and so it almost always happens that when a matter is well brought into shape for discussion, it is exploded by some unreasonable clamor and petulance, and angry feeling, commonly dissembled, indeed, but sometimes plainly expressed; it has been, as I think, most advantageous, and most answerable to peace, that the resolution was made by thee to seek truth in the way of question by me and answer by thee: wherefore there is no reason why you should fear, if at any point you have unadvisedly tied yourself up, to return and undo the knots; for otherwise there is no escape from hence.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:2
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:3
verses.text: Thou speakest rightly; but what I have granted amiss I altogether fail to see: unless perchance that that is rightly called false which has some similitude of the true, since assuredly nothing else occurs to me worthy of the name of false; and yet again I am compelled to confess that those things which are called false are so called by the fact that  they differ from the true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:4
verses.text: From which it resuits that that very dissimilitude is the cause of the falsity.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:5
verses.text: Therefore I am disquieted; for I cannot easily call to mind anything that is engendered by contrary causes.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:6
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:7
verses.text: What if this is the one and only kind in the universe of things which is so? Or are you ignorant, that in running over the innumerable species of animals, the crocodile alone is found to move its upper jaw in eating; especially as scarcely anything can be discovered so like to another thing, that it is not also in some point unlike it? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:8
verses.text: I see that indeed; but when I consider that that which we call false has both something like and something unlike the true, I am not able to make out on which side it chiefly merits the name of false.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:9
verses.text: For if I say: on the side on which it is unlike; there will be nothing which cannot be called false: for there is nothing which is not dissimilar to some thing, which we concede to be true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:10
verses.text: And again, if I shall say, that it is to be called false on that side on which it is similar; not only will those eggs cry out against us which are true on the very ground of their excessive similarity, but even so I shall not escape from his grasp who may compel me to confess that all things are false because I cannot deny that all things are on some side or other similar to each other.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:11
verses.text: But suppose me not afraid to give this answer, that likeness and unlikeness alike give a right to call anything false; what way of escape wilt thou give me? For none the less will the fatal necessity hang over me of proclaiming all things false; since, as has been said above, all things are found to be both similar, on some side, and dissimilar, on some side, to each other.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:12
verses.text: My only remaining resource would be to declare nothing else false, except what was other than it seemed, unless I shrank from again encountering all those monsters, which I flattered myself that I had long since sailed away from.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:13
verses.text: For a whirlpool again seizes me at unawares, and brings me round to own that to be true which is as it seems.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:14
verses.text: From which it results that without a knower nothing can be true: where I have to fear a shipwreck on deeply hidden rocks, which are true, although unknown.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:15
verses.text: Or, if I shall say that that is true which is, it follows, let who will oppose, that there is nothing false anywhere.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 15:16
verses.text: And so I see the same breakers before me again, and see that all my patience of thy delays has helped me forward nothing at all.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 16:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 16:3
verses.text: Attend rather; for never can I be persuaded, that we have implored the Divine aid in vain.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 16:4
verses.text: For I see that, having tried all things as far as we could, we found nothing to remain, which could rightly be called false, except what either feigns itself to be what it is not, or, to include all, tends to be and is not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 16:5
verses.text: But that former kind of falsity is either fallacious or mendacious.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 16:6
verses.text: For that is rightly called fallacious which has a certain appetite of deceiving; which cannot be understood as without a soul: but this results in part from reason, in part from nature; from reason, in rational creatures, as in men; from nature, in beasts, as in the fox.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 16:7
verses.text: But what I call mendacious, proceeds from those who utter falsehood.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 16:8
verses.text: Who in this point differ from the fallacious, that all the fallacious seek to mislead; but not every one who utters falsehood, wishes to mislead; for both mimes and comedies and many poems are full of falsehoods, rather with the purpose of delighting than of misleading, and almost all those who jest utter falsehood.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 16:9
verses.text: But he is rightly called fallacious, whose purpose is, that somebody should be deceived.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 16:10
verses.text: But those who do not aim to deceive, but nevertheless feign somewhat, are mendacious only, or if not even this, no one at least doubts that they are to be called pleasant falsifiers: unless you have something to object.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:2
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:3
verses.text: Proceed, I pray; for now perchance thou hast begun to teach concerning falsities not falsely: but now I am considering of what sort that class of falsities may be, of which thou hast said, It tends to be, and is not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:4
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:5
verses.text: Why should you not consider? They are the same things, which already we have largely passed review.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:6
verses.text: Does not thy image in the mirror appear to will to be thou thyself, but to be therefore false, because it is not? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:7
verses.text: This does, in very deed, seem so.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:8
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:9
verses.text: And as to pictures, and all such expressed resemblances, every such thing wrought by the artist? Do they not press to be that, after whose similitude they have been made? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:10
verses.text: I must certainly own this to be true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:11
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:12
verses.text: And you will allow, I believe, that the deceits under which dreamers, or madmen suffer, are to be included in this kind.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:13
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:14
verses.text: None more: for none tend more to be such things as the waking and the sane discern; and yet they are hereby false, because that which they tend to be they cannot be.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:15
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:16
verses.text: Why need I now say more concerning the gliding towers, or the dipped oar, or the shadows of bodies? It is plain, as I think, that they are to be measured by this rule.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:17
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:18
verses.text: Most evidently they are.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:19
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 17:20
verses.text: I say nothing concerning the remaining senses; for no one by consideration will fail to find this, that in the various things which are subject to our sense, that is called false which tends to be anything and is not.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:2
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:3
verses.text: Thou speakest rightly; but I wonder why thou wouldst separate from this class those poems and jests, and other imitative trifles.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:4
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:5
verses.text: Because forsooth it is one thing to will to be false, and another not to be able to be true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:6
verses.text: Therefore these works of men themselves, such as comedies or tragedies, or mimes, and other such things, we may include with the works of painters and sculptors.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:7
verses.text: For a painted man cannot be so true, however much he may tend into the form of man, as those things which are written in the books of the comic poets.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:8
verses.text: For neither do they will to be false, nor are they false by any appetite of their own; but by a certain necessity, so far as they have been able to follow the mind of the author.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:9
verses.text: But on the stage Roscius in will was a false Hecuba, in nature a true man; but by that will also a true tragedian, in that he was fulfilling the thing proposed: but a false Priam, in that he made himself like Priam, but was not he.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:10
verses.text: From which now arises a certain marvellous thing, which nevertheless no one doubts to be so.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:11
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:12
verses.text: What, pray, is it? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:13
verses.text: What think you, unless that all these things are in certain aspects true, by this very thing that they are in certain aspects false, and that for their quality of truth this alone avails them, that they are false in another regard? Whence to that which they either will or ought to be, they in no wise attain, if they avoid being false.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:14
verses.text: For how could he whom I have mentioned have been a true tragedian, had he been unwilling to be a false Hector, a false Andromache, a false Hercules, and innumerable other things? or how would a picture, for instance, be a true picture, unless it were a false horse? or how could there be in a mirror a true image of a man, if it were not a false man? Wherefore, if it avails some things that they be somewhat false in order that they may be somewhat true; why do we so greatly dread falsity, and seek truth as the greatest good? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:15
verses.text: I know not, and I greatly marvel, unless because in these examples I see nothing worthy of imitation.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:16
verses.text: For not as actors, or specular reflections, or Myron's brazen cows, ought we, in order that we may be true in some character of our own, to be outlined and accommodated to the personation of another; but to seek that truth, which is not, as if laid out on a bifronted and self-repugnant plan, false on one side that it may be true on the other.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:17
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:18
verses.text: High and Divine are the things which thou requirest.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:19
verses.text: Yet if we shall have found them, shall we not confess that of these things is Truth itself made up, and as it were brought into being from their fusion—Truth, from which every thing derives its name which in any way is called true? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 18:20
verses.text: I yield no unwilling assent.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:3
verses.text: What then think you? Is the science of debate true, or false? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:4
verses.text: True, beyond controversy.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:5
verses.text: But Grammar too is true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:6
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:7
verses.text: In the same sense as the former? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:8
verses.text: I do not see what is truer than the true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:9
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:10
verses.text: That assuredly which has nothing of false: in view of which a little while ago thou didst take umbrage at those things which, be it in this way or that, unless they were false, could not be true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:11
verses.text: Or do you not know, that all those fabulous and openly false things appertain to Grammar? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:12
verses.text: I am not ignorant of that indeed; but, as I judge, it is not through Grammar that they are false, but through it, that, whatever they may be, they are interpreted.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:13
verses.text: Since a drama is a falsehood composed for utility or delight.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:14
verses.text: But Grammar is a science which is the guardian and moderatrix of articulate speech: whose profession involves the necessity of collecting even all the figments of the human tongue, which have been committed to memory and letters, not making them false, but teaching and enforcing concerning these certain principles of true interpretation.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:15
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:16
verses.text: Very just: I care not now, whether or not these things have been well defined and distinguished by thee; but this I ask, whether it is Grammar itself, or that science of debate which shows this to be so.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:17
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 19:18
verses.text: I do not deny that the force and skill of definition, whereby I have now endeavored to separate these things, is to be attributed to the art of disputation.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:3
verses.text: How as to Grammar itself? if it is true, is it not so far true as it is a discipline? For the name of Discipline signifies something to be learnt: but no one who has learned and who retains what he learns, can be said not to know; and no one knows falsities.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:4
verses.text: Therefore every discipline and science is true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:5
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:6
verses.text: I see not what rashness there can be in assenting to this brief course of reasoning.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:7
verses.text: But I am disturbed lest it should bring any one to suppose those dramas to be true; for these also we learn and retain.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:8
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:9
verses.text: Was then our master unwilling that we should believe what he taught, and know it? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:10
verses.text: Nay, he was thoroughly in earnest that we should know it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:11
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:12
verses.text: And did he, pray, ever set out to have us believe that Daedalus flew? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:13
verses.text: That, indeed, never.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:14
verses.text: But assuredly unless we remembered the poem, he took such order that we were scarcely able to hold anything in our hands.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:15
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:16
verses.text: Do you then deny it to be true that there is such a poem, and that such a tradition is spread abroad concerning Daedalus? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:17
verses.text: I do not deny this to be true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:18
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:19
verses.text: You do not then deny that you learned the  truth, when you learned these things.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:20
verses.text: For if it is true that Daedalus flew, and boys should receive and recite this as a feigning fable, they would be laying up falsities in mind by the very fact that the things were true which they recited.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:21
verses.text: For from this results what we were admiring above, that there could not be a true fiction turning on the flight of Daedalus, unless it were false that Daedalus flew.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:22
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:23
verses.text: I now grasp that; but what good is to come of it, I do not yet see.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:24
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:25
verses.text: What, unless that that course of reasoning is not false, whereby we gather that a science, unless it is true, cannot be a science? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:26
verses.text: And what does this signify? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:27
verses.text: Because I wish to have you tell me on what the science of Grammar rests: for the truth of the science rests on that very principle which makes it a science.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:28
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:29
verses.text: I know not what to answer thee.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:30
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:31
verses.text: Does it not seem to you, that if nothing in it had been defined, and nothing distributed and distinguished into classes and parts, it could not in any wise be a true science? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:32
verses.text: Now I grasp thy meaning: nor does the remembrance of any science whatever occur to me, in which definitions and divisions and processes of reasoning do not, inasmuch as it is declared what each thing is, as without confusion of parts its proper attributes are ascribed to each class, nothing peculiar to it being neglected, nothing alien to it admitted, perform that whole range of functions from which it has the name of Science.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:33
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:34
verses.text: That whole range of functions therefore from which it has the name of true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:35
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 20:36
verses.text: I see this to be implied.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:3
verses.text: Tell me now what science contains the principles of definitions, divisions and partitions.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:4
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:5
verses.text: It has been said above that these are contained in the rules of disputation.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:6
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:7
verses.text: Grammar therefore, both as a science, and as a true science, has been created by the same art which has above been defended from the charge of falsity.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:8
verses.text: Which conclusion I am not required to confine to Grammar alone, but am permitted to extend to all sciences whatever.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:9
verses.text: For you have said, and truly said, that no science occurs to you, in which the law of defining and distributing does not lie at the very foundation of its character as a science.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:10
verses.text: But if they are true on that ground on which they are sciences, will any one deny that very thing to be truth through which all the sciences are true? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:11
verses.text: Assuredly I find it hard to withhold assent: but this gives me pause, that we reckon among the sciences even that theory of disputation.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:12
verses.text: Wherefore I judge that rather to be truth, whereby this theory itself is true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:13
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:14
verses.text: Your watchful accuracy is indeed most highly to be commended: but you do not deny, I suppose, that it is true on the same ground on which it is a theory and science.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:15
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:16
verses.text: Nay, that is my very ground of perplexity.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:17
verses.text: For I have noted that it also is a science, and is on this account called true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:18
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:19
verses.text: What then? Do you think this could be a science on any other ground than that all things in it were defined and distributed? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:20
verses.text: I have nothing else to say.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:21
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:22
verses.text: But if this function appertains to it, it is in and of itself a true science.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:23
verses.text: Why then should any one find it wonderful, if that truth whereby all things are true, should be through itself and in itself true? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 21:24
verses.text: Nothing stands now in the way of my giving an unreserved assent to that opinion.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:3
verses.text: Attend therefore to the few things that remain.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:4
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:5
verses.text: Bring forth whatever thou hast, if only it be such as I can understand, and I will willingly agree.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:6
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:7
verses.text: We do not forget, that to say that anything is in anything, is capable of a double sense.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:8
verses.text: It may mean that it is so in such a sense as that it can also be disjoined and be elsewhere, as this wood in this place, or the sun in the East.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:9
verses.text: Or it may mean anything is so in a subject, that it cannot be separated from it, as in this wood the shape and visible appearance, as in the sun the light, as in fire heat, as in the mind discipline, and such like.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:10
verses.text: Or seems it otherwise to thee? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:11
verses.text: These distinctions are indeed most thoroughly familiar to us, and from early youth most studiously made an element of thought; wherefore, if asked about these, I must needs grant the position at once.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:12
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:13
verses.text: But do you not concede that if the subject do not abide, that which is in the subject cannot inseparably abide? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:14
verses.text: This also I see necessary: for, the subject remaining, that which is in the subject may possibly not remain, as any one with a little thought can perceive.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:15
verses.text: Since the color of this body of mine may, by reason of health or age, suffer change, though the body has not yet perished.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:16
verses.text: And this is not equally true of all things, but of those whose coexistence with the subject is not necessary to the existence of the subject.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:17
verses.text: For it is not necessary that this wall, in order to be a wall, should be of this color, which we see in it; for even if, by some chance, it should become black or white, or should undergo some other change of color, it would nevertheless remain a wall and be so called.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 22:18
verses.text: But if fire were without heat, it will not even be fire; nor can we talk of snow except as being white.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:2
verses.text: But as to thy question, who would grant, or to whom could it appear possible, that that which is in the subject should remain,  while the subject perished? For it is monstrous and most utterly foreign to the truth that what would not be unless it were in the subject, could be even when the subject itself was no more.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:3
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:4
verses.text: Then that which we were seeking is found.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:5
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:6
verses.text: What dost thou mean? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:7
verses.text: What you hear.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:8
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:9
verses.text: And is it then now clearly made out that the mind is immortal? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:10
verses.text: If these things which you have granted are true, with most indisputable clearness: unless perchance you would say that the mind, even though it die, is still the mind.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:11
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:12
verses.text: I, at least, will never say that; but by this very fact that it perishes it then comes about that it is not the mind, is what I do say.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:13
verses.text: Nor am I shaken in this opinion because it has been said by great philosophers that that thing which, wherever it comes, affords life, cannot admit death into itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:14
verses.text: For although the light wheresoever it has been able to gain entrance, makes that place luminous, and, by virtue of that memorable force of contrarieties, cannot admit darkness into itself; yet it is extinguished, and that place is by its extinction made dark.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:15
verses.text: So that which resisted the darkness, neither in any way admitted the darkness into it, and yet made place for it by perishing, as it could have made place for it by departing.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:16
verses.text: Therefore I fear lest death should befall the body in such wise as darkness a place, the mind, like light, sometimes departing, but sometimes being extinguished on the spot; so that now not concerning every death of the body is there security, but a particular kind of death is to be chosen, by which the soul may be conducted out of the body unharmed, and guided to a place, if there is any such place, where it cannot be extinguished.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:17
verses.text: Or, if not even this may be, and the mind, as it were a light, is kindled in the body itself, nor has capacity to endure elsewhere, and every death is a sort of extinction of the soul in the body, or of the life; some sort is to be chosen by which, so far as man is allowed, life, while it is lived, may be lived in security and tranquillity, although I know not how that can come to pass if the soul dies.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 23:18
verses.text: O greatly blessed they, who, whether from themselves, or from whom you will, have gained the persuasion, that death is not to be feared, even if the soul should perish! But, wretched me, no reasonings, no books, have hitherto been able to persuade of this.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:3
verses.text: Groan not, the human mind is immortal.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:4
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:5
verses.text: How dost thou prove it? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:6
verses.text: From those things which you have granted above, with great caution.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:7
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:8
verses.text: I do not indeed recall to mind any want of vigilance in my admissions when questioned by thee: but now gather all into one sum, I pray thee; let us see at what point we have arrived after so many circuits, nor would I have thee in doing so question me.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:9
verses.text: For if thou art about to enumerate concisely those things which I have granted, why is my response again desired? Or is it that thou wouldst wantonly torture me by delays of joy, if we have in fact achieved any solid result? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:10
verses.text: I will do that which I see that thou dost wish, but attend most diligently.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:11
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:12
verses.text: Speak now, here I am; why slayest thou me? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:13
verses.text: If everything which is in the subject always abides, it follows of necessity that the subject itself always abides.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:14
verses.text: And every discipline is in the subject mind.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:15
verses.text: It is necessary therefore that the mind should continue forever, if the science continues forever.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:16
verses.text: Now Science is Truth, and always, as in the beginning of this book Reason hath convinced thee, does Truth abide.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:17
verses.text: Therefore the mind lasts forever, nor dead, could it be called the mind.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 24:18
verses.text: He therefore alone can escape absurdity in denying the mind to be immortal, who can prove that any of the foregoing concessions have been made without reason.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 25:2
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 25:3
verses.text: And now I am ready to plunge into the expected joys, but yet I am held hesitating by two thoughts.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 25:4
verses.text: For, first, it makes me uneasy that we have used so long a circuit, following out I know not what chain of reasonings, when the whole matter of discourse admitted of so brief a demonstration, as has now been shown.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 25:5
verses.text: Wherefore, it renders me anxious that the discourse has so long held so wary a step, as if with some design of setting an ambush.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 25:6
verses.text: Next, I do not see how a science is always in the mind, when, on the one hand, so few are familiar with it, and, on the other, whoever does know it, was during so long a time of early childhood unacquainted with it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 25:7
verses.text: For we can neither say that the minds of the untaught are not minds, nor that that science is in their mind of which they are ignorant.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 25:8
verses.text: And if this is utterly absurd, it results that either the science is not always in the mind, or that that science is not Truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 26:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 26:3
verses.text: Thou mayest note that it is not for naught that our reasoning has taken so wide a round.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 26:4
verses.text: For we were inquiring what is Truth, which not even now, in this very forest of thoughts and things, beguiling our steps into an infinity of paths, have we, as I see, been able to track out to the end.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 26:5
verses.text: But what are we to do? Shall we desist from our undertaking, and wait in hope that some book or other may fall into our hands, which may satisfy this question?
