For many, I think, have written before our age, whom we  have not read: and now, to give no guess at what we do not know, we see plainly that there is much writing upon this theme, both in verse and prose; and that by men whose writings cannot be unknown to us, and whose genius we know to be such, that we cannot despair of finding in their works what we require: especially when here before our eyes is he in whom we have recognized that eloquence for which we mourned as dead, to have revived in vigorous life.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 26:6
verses.text: Will he suffer us, after having in his writings taught us the true manner of living, to remain ignorant of the true nature of living? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 26:7
verses.text: I indeed do not think so, and hope much from thence but one matter of grief I have, that we have not opportunity of opening to him our zealous affection either towards him or towards Wisdom.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 26:8
verses.text: For assuredly he would pity our thirst and would overflow much more quickly than now.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 26:9
verses.text: For he is secure, because he has now won a full conviction of the immortality of the soul, and perhaps knows not that there are any, who have only too well experienced the misery of this ignorance, and whom it is cruel not to aid, especially when they entreat it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 26:10
verses.text: But that other knows indeed from old familiarity our ardor of longing; but he is so far removed, and we are so circumstanced, that we have scarcely the opportunity of so much as sending a letter to him.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 26:11
verses.text: Whom I believe to have lately in Transalpine retirement composed a spell, under whose ban the fear of death is compelled to flee, and the cold stupor of the soul, indurate with lasting ice, is expelled.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 26:12
verses.text: But in the meantime, while these helps are leisurely making their way hither, a benefit which it is not in our power to command, is it not most unworthy that our leisure should be wasting, and our very mind hang wholly dependent on the uncertain decision of another's will?.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 27:2
verses.text: What shall we say to this, that we have entreated God and do entreat, that He will show us a way, not to riches, not to bodily pleasures, not to popular honors and seats of state, but to the knowledge of our own soul, and that He will likewise disclose Himself to them that seek Him? Will He, indeed, forsake us, or shall He be forsaken by us? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 27:3
verses.text: Most utterly foreign to Him is it indeed, that He should desert them who desire such things: whence also it ought to be strange to our thoughts that we should desert so great a Guide.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 27:4
verses.text: Wherefore, if you will, let us briefly go over the considerations from which either proposition results, either that Truth always abides, or that Truth is the theory of argumentation.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 27:5
verses.text: For you have said that these points wavered in your mind, so as to make us less secure of the final conclusion of the whole matter.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 27:6
verses.text: Or shall we rather inquire this, how a science can be in an untrained mind, which yet we cannot deny to be a mind? For this seemed to give you uneasiness, so as to involve you again in doubt as to your previous concessions.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 27:7
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 27:8
verses.text: Nay, let us first discuss the two former propositions, and then we will consider the nature of this latter fact.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 27:9
verses.text: For so, as I judge, no controversy will remain.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 27:10
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 27:11
verses.text: So be it, but attend with the utmost heed and caution.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 27:12
verses.text: For I know what happens to you as you listen, namely, that while you are too intent upon the conclusion, and expecting that now, or now, it will be drawn, you grant the points implied in my questions without a sufficiently diligent scrutiny.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 27:13
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 27:14
verses.text: Perchance thou speakest the truth; but I shall strive against this kind of disease as much as I can: only begin thou now to inquire of me, that we linger not over things superfluous.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:3
verses.text: From this truth, as I remember, that Truth cannot perish, we have concluded, that not only if the whole world should perish, but even if Truth itself should, it will still be true that both the world and Truth have perished.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:4
verses.text: Now there is nothing true without truth: in no wise therefore does Truth perish.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:5
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:6
verses.text: I acknowledge all this, and shall be greatly surprised if it turns out false.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:7
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:8
verses.text: Let us then consider that other point.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:9
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:10
verses.text: Suffer me, I pray thee, to reflect a little, lest I should soon come back in confusion.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:11
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:12
verses.text: Will it therefore not be true that Truth has perished? If it will not be true, then Truth does not perish.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:13
verses.text: If it were true, where, after the fall of Truth, will be the true, when now there is no truth? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:14
verses.text: I have no further occasion for thought and consideration; proceed to something else.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 28:15
verses.text: Assuredly we will take order, so far as we may, that learned and wise men may read these musings, and may correct our unadvisedness, if they shall find any: for as to myself, I do not believe that either now or hereafter I shall be able to discover what can be said against this.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:3
verses.text: Is Truth then so called for any other reason than as being that by which everything is true which is true? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:4
verses.text: For no other reason.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:5
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:6
verses.text: Is it rightly called true for any ground than that it is not false? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:7
verses.text: To doubt this were madness.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:8
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:9
verses.text: Is that not false which is accommodated to the similitude of anything, yet is not that the likeness of which it appears? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:10
verses.text: Nothing indeed do I see which I would more willingly call false.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:11
verses.text: But yet that is commonly called false, which is far removed from the similitude of the true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:12
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:13
verses.text: Who denies it? But yet because  it implies some imitation of the true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:14
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:15
verses.text: How? For when it is said, that Medea flew away with winged snakes harnessed to her car, that thing on no side imitates truth; inasmuch as the thing is naught, nor can that thing imitate aught, when itself is absolutely nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:16
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:17
verses.text: You say right; but you do not note that that thing which is absolutely nothing, cannot even be called false.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:18
verses.text: For if it is false, it is: if it is not, it is not false.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:19
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:20
verses.text: Shall we not then say that monstrous story of Medea is false? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:21
verses.text: Assuredly not; for if it is false, how is it a monstrous story? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:22
verses.text: Admirable! Then when I say  "The mighty winged snakes I fasten to my car,"  do I not say false? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:23
verses.text: You do, assuredly: for that is which you say to be false.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:24
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:25
verses.text: What, I pray? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:26
verses.text: That sentence, forsooth, which is contained in the verse itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:27
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:28
verses.text: And pray what imitation of truth has that? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:29
verses.text: Because it would bear the same tenor, even if Medea had truly done that thing.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:30
verses.text: Therefore in its very terms a false sentence imitates true sentences.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:31
verses.text: Which, if it is not believed, in this alone does it imitate true ones, that it is expressed as they, and it is only false, it is not also misleading.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:32
verses.text: But if it obtains faith, it imitates also those sentences which, being true, are believed true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:33
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:34
verses.text: Now I perceive that there is a great difference between those things which we say and those things concerning which we say aught; wherefore I now assent: for this proposition alone held me back, that whatever we call false is not rightly so called, unless it have an imitation of something true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:35
verses.text: For who, calling a stone false silver, would not be justly derided? Yet if any one should declare a stone to be silver, we say that he speaks falsely, that is, that he utters a false sentence.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 29:36
verses.text: But it is not, I think, unreasonable that we should call tin or lead false silver, because the thing itself, as it were, imitates that: nor is our sentence declaring this therefore false, but that very thing concerning which it is pronounced.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:3
verses.text: You apprehend the matter well.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:4
verses.text: But consider this, whether we can also with propriety call silver by the name of false lead.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:5
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:6
verses.text: Not in my opinion.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:7
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:8
verses.text: Why so? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:9
verses.text: I know not; except that I see that it would be altogether against my will to have it so called.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:10
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:11
verses.text: Is it perchance for the reason that silver is the better, and such a name would be contemptuous of it; but it confers a certain honor, as it were, on lead, if it should be called false silver? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:12
verses.text: Thou hast expressed exactly what I had in mind.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:13
verses.text: And therefore I believe that it is with good right that those are held infamous and incapable of bearing witness, who flaunt themselves in female attire, whom I know not whether I should more reasonably call false women, or false men.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:14
verses.text: True actors, however, and truly infamous, without doubt we can call them; or, if they lurk unseen, and if infamy implies an evil repute, we may call them not without truth, true specimens of worthlessness.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:15
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:16
verses.text: We shall have another opportunity of discussing these things: for many things are done, which in the mere guise of them appear base, yet, done for some praiseworthy end, are shown to be honorable.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:17
verses.text: And it is a great question whether one, for the sake of liberating his country, ought to put on a woman's garment to deceive the enemy, being, perhaps, by the very fact that he is a false woman, apt to be shown the truer man: and whether a wise man who in some way may have certainly ascertained that his life will be necessary to the interests of mankind, ought to choose rather to die of cold, than to indue himself in female vestments, if he can find no other.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:18
verses.text: But concerning this, as has been said, we will consider hereafter.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:19
verses.text: For unquestionably thou discernest how careful an inquisition it requires, how far such things can be carried, without falling into various inexcusable basenesses.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 30:20
verses.text: But now—which suffices for the present question—I think it is now evident, and beyond doubt, that there is not anything false except by some imitation of the true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:2
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:3
verses.text: Go on to what remains; for of this I am well convinced.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:4
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:5
verses.text: Then I ask this, whether, besides the sciences in which we are instructed, and in which it is fitting that the study of wisdom itself should be included, we can find anything so true, that it is not, like that Achilles of the stage, false on one side, that it may be true on another? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:6
verses.text: To me, indeed, many such things appear capable of being found.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:7
verses.text: For no sciences contain this stone, nor yet, that it may be a true stone, does it imitate anything according to which it would be called false.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:8
verses.text: Which one thing being mentioned, thou seest there is opportunity to dwell upon things innumerable, which of themselves occur to the thought.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:9
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:10
verses.text: I see, I see.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:11
verses.text: But do they not seem to thee to be included in the one name of Body? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:12
verses.text: They might so seem, if either I had ascertained the inane to be nothing, or thought that the mind itself ought to be numbered among bodies, or believed that God also is a body.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:13
verses.text: If all these things are, I see them not to be false and true in imitation of anything.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:14
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:15
verses.text: You send us a long journey, but I will use all compendious speed.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:16
verses.text: For certainly what you call the Inane is one thing, what you call Truth another.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:17
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:18
verses.text: Widely diverse, indeed.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:19
verses.text: For  what more inane than I, if I think Truth anything inane, or so greatly seek after aught inane? For what else than Truth do I desire to find? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:20
verses.text: Therefore perchance you grant this too, that nothing is true which does not by Truth come to be true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:21
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:22
verses.text: This became manifest at an early stage.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:23
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:24
verses.text: Do you doubt that nothing is inane except the Inane itself, or certainly that a body is not inane? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:25
verses.text: I do not doubt it at all.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:26
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:27
verses.text: I suppose therefore, you believe that Truth is some sort of body.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:28
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:29
verses.text: In no wise.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:30
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:31
verses.text: What is a body? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:32
verses.text: I know not; no matter: for I think thou knowest that even that inane, if it is inane, is more completely so where there is no body.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:33
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:34
verses.text: This assuredly is plain.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:35
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:36
verses.text: Why then do we delay? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:37
verses.text: Does it then seem to thee either that Truth made the inane, or that there is anything true where Truth is not? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:38
verses.text: Neither seems true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:39
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:40
verses.text: The inane therefore is not true, because neither could it become inane by that which is not inane: and it is manifest that what is void of truth is not true; and, in fine, that very thing which is called inane, is so called because it is nothing.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:41
verses.text: How therefore can that be true which is not or how can that be which is absolutely nothing? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 31:42
verses.text: Well then, let us desert the inane as being inane.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:3
verses.text: What sayest thou concerning the rest? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:4
verses.text: What? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:5
verses.text: Because you see how much stands on my side.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:6
verses.text: For we have remaining the Soul and God.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:7
verses.text: And if these two are true for the reason that Truth is in them of the immortality of God no one doubts.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:8
verses.text: But the mind is believed immortal, if Truth which cannot perish, is proved to be in it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:9
verses.text: Wherefore let as consider this last point, whether the body be not truly true, that is, whether there be in it, not Truth, but a certain image of Truth.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:10
verses.text: For if even in the body, which we know to be perishable, we find such an element of truth, as there is in the sciences, it does not then so certainly follow, that the art of discussion is Truth, whereby all sciences are true.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:11
verses.text: For true is even the body, which does not seem to have been formed by the force of argument.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:12
verses.text: But if even the body is true by a certain imitation, and is on this account, not absolutely and purely true, there will then, perchance, be nothing to hinder the theory of argument from being taught to be Truth itself.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:13
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:14
verses.text: Meanwhile let us inquire concerning the body; for not even when this shall have been settled, do I see a prospect of ending this controversy.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:15
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:16
verses.text: Whence knowest thou what God purposes? Therefore attend: for I at least think the body to be contained in a certain form and guise, which if it had not, it would not be the body; if it had it in truth, it would be the mind.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:17
verses.text: Or does the fact stand otherwise? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:18
verses.text: I assent in part, of the rest I doubt; for, unless some figure is maintained, I grant that it is not a body.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:19
verses.text: But how, if it had it in truth, it would be the mind, I do not well understand.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:20
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:21
verses.text: Do you then remember nothing concerning the exordium of this book, and that Geometry of yours? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:22
verses.text: Thou hast mentioned it to purpose; I do indeed remember, and am most willing to do so.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:23
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:24
verses.text: Are such figures found in bodies, as that science demonstrates? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:25
verses.text: Nay, it is incredible how greatly inferior they are convicted of being.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:26
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:27
verses.text: Which of them, therefore, do you think true? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:28
verses.text: Do not, I beg, think it necessary even to put that question to me.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 32:29
verses.text: For who is so dull, as not to see that those figures which are taught in Geometry, dwell in Truth itself, or even Truth in these; but that those embodied figures, inasmuch as, they seem, so to speak, to tend towards these, have I know not what imitation of truth, and are therefore false? For now that whole matter which thou wert laboring to show, I understand.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:3
verses.text: What need is there any longer than that we should inquire concerning the science of disputation? For whether the figures of Geometry are in the Truth, or the Truth is in them, that they are contained in our soul, that, is, in our intelligence, no one calls in question, and through this fact Truth also is compelled to be in our mind.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:4
verses.text: But if every science whatever is so in the mind, as in the subject inseparably, and if Truth is not able to perish; why, I ask, do we doubt concerning the perpetual life of the mind through I know not what familiarity with death? Or have that line or squareness or roundness other things which they imitate that they may be true? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:5
verses.text: In no way can I believe that, unless perchance a line be something else than length without breadth, and a circle something else than a circumscribed line everywhere verging equally to the centre.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:6
verses.text: Why then do we hesitate? Or is not Truth where these things are? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:7
verses.text: God avert such madness.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:8
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:9
verses.text: Or is not the science in the mind? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:10
verses.text: Who would say that? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:11
verses.text: But is it possible, the subject perishing, that that which is in the subject should perdure? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:12
verses.text: When could I imagine such a thing? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:13
verses.text: It remains to suppose that Truth may fail.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:14
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:15
verses.text: Whence could this be brought to pass? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:16
verses.text: Therefore the soul is immortal: now at last yield to thine own arguments, believe the Truth; she cries out that she dwelleth in thee, and is immortal, and that her seat cannot be withdrawn from her by any possible death of  the body.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:17
verses.text: Turn away from thy shadow, return into thyself; of no meaning is the destruction thou fearest, except that thou hast forgotten that thou canst not be destroyed.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:18
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:19
verses.text: I hear, I come to a better mind, I begin to recollect myself.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:20
verses.text: But I beg thou wouldst expedite those things which remain; how, in an undisciplined mind, for a mortal one we cannot call it, Science and Truth are to be understood to be.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:21
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:22
verses.text: That question requires another volume, if thou wouldst have it treated thoroughly: moreover also I see occasion for thee to review those things, which, after our best power, have been already examined; because if no one of those things which have been admitted is doubtful, I think that we have accomplished much, and with no small security may proceed to push our inquiries farther.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:24
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:25
verses.text: It is as thou sayest, and I willingly yield compliance with thine injunctions.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:26
verses.text: But this at least I would entreat, before thou decreest a term to the volume, that thou wouldst summarily explain what the distinction is between the true figure, which is contained in the intelligence, and that which thought frames to itself, which in Greek is termed either Phantasia or Phantasma.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:27
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:28
verses.text: Thou seekest that which no one except one of purest sight is able to see, and to the vision of which thing thou art but poorly trained; nor have we now in these wide circuits anything else in view than to exercise thee, that thou mayest be competent to see: yet how it is possible to be taught that the difference is very great, perhaps I can, with a little pains, make clear.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:29
verses.text: For suppose thou hadst forgotten something, and that others were wishing that thou shouldst recall it to memory.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:30
verses.text: They therefore say: Is it this, or that? bringing forward things diverse from it as if similar to it.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:31
verses.text: But thou neither seest that which thou desirest to recollect, and yet seest that it is not this which is suggested.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:32
verses.text: Seems this to thee, when it happens, by any means equivalent to total forgetfulness? For this very power of distinguishing, whereby the false suggestions made to time are repelled, is a certain part of recollection.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:33
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:34
verses.text: So it seems.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:35
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:36
verses.text: Such therefore do not yet see the truth yet they cannot be misled and deceived; and what they seek, they sufficiently know.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:37
verses.text: But if any one should say that thou didst laugh a few days after thou wast born, thou wouldst not venture to say it was false: and if he were an authority worthy of credit, thou art ready, not, indeed, to remember, but to believe; for to thee that whole time is buried in most authentic oblivion.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:38
verses.text: Or thinkest thou otherwise? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:39
verses.text: I thoroughly agree with this.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:40
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:41
verses.text: This oblivion therefore differs exceedingly from that, but that stands midway.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:42
verses.text: For there is another nearer and more closely neighboring to the recollection and rekindled vision of truth: the like of which is when we see something, and recognize for certain that we have seen it at some time, and affirm that we know it; but where, or when, or how, or with whom it came into our knowledge, we have enough to do to search our memory for an answer.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:43
verses.text: As if this happens in regard to a man, we also inquire where we have known him: which when he has brought to mind, suddenly the whole thing flashes upon the memory like a light, and we have no more trouble to recollect.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:44
verses.text: Is this sort of forgetfulness unknown to thee, or obscure? A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 33:45
verses.text: What plainer than this or what is happening to me more frequently?.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 34:2
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 34:3
verses.text: Such are those who are well instructed in the liberal arts; since they by learning disinter them, buried in oblivion, doubtless, within themselves, and, in a manner, dig them out afresh: nor yet are they content, nor refrain themselves until the whole aspect of Truth, of which, in those arts, a certain effulgence already gleams forth upon them, is by them most widely and most clearly beheld.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 34:4
verses.text: But from this certain false colors and forms pour themselves as it were upon the mirror of thought, and mislead inquirers often, and deceive those who think that to be the whole which they know or which they inquire.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 34:5
verses.text: Those imaginations themselves are to be avoided with great carefulness; which are detected as fallacious, by their varying with the varied mirror of thought, whereas that face of Truth abides one and immutable.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 34:6
verses.text: For then thought portrays to itself, for instance, a square of this or that or the other magnitude, and, as it were, brings it before the eyes; but the inner mind which wishes to see the truth, applies itself rather to that general conception, if it can, according to which it judges all these to be squares.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 34:7
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 34:8
verses.text: What if some one should say to us that the mind judges according to what it is accustomed to see with the eyes? R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 34:9
verses.text: Why then does it judge, that is, if it is well trained, that a true sphere of any conceivable size is touched by a true plane at a point? How has eye ever seen, or how can eye ever see such a thing, when anything of this kind cannot be bodied forth in the pure imagination of thought? Or do we not prove this, when we describe even the smallest imaginary circle in our mind, and from it draw lines to the centre? For when we have drawn two, between which there is scarce room for a needle's point, we are no longer able, even in imagination, to draw  others between, so that they shall arrive at the centre without any commixture; whereas reason exclaims that innumerable lines can be drawn, without being able to touch each other except in the centre, so that in every interval between them even a circle could be described.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 34:10
verses.text: Since that Phantasy cannot accomplish this, and is more deficient than the eyes themselves, since it is through them that it is inflicted on the mind, it is manifest that it differs much from Truth, and that that, when this is seen, is not seen.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 35:2
verses.text: These points will be treated with more pains and greater subtilty, when we shall have begun to discuss the faculty of intelligence, which part of our theme is proposed by us, as something which is to be developed and discussed by us, when anything gives anxiety concerning the life of the soul.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 35:3
verses.text: For I believe thee to stand in no slight fear lest the death of man, even if it do not slay the soul, should nevertheless induce oblivion of all things, and of Truth itself, if any shall have been discovered.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 35:4
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 35:5
verses.text: It cannot be expressed how much this evil is to be feared.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 35:6
verses.text: For of what sort will be that eternal life, or what death is not to be preferred to it, if the soul so lives, as we see it live in a child just born? to say nothing of that life which is lived in the womb; for I do not think it to be none.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 35:7
verses.text: R.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 35:8
verses.text: Be of good courage; God will be present, as we now feel, to us who seek, who promises a certain most blessed body after this, and an utter plenitude of Truth without any falsehood.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 35:9
verses.text: A.

verses.name: Augustine: Soliloquies Book II 35:10
verses.text: May it be as we hope.
